column1: Piteå is a locality and the seat of Piteå Municipality in Norrbotten County
column2: Sweden.

column1: Piteå is located at the mouth of the Pite River (Swedish: Piteälven)
column2: at the shore of the Bay of Bothnia. The central part is located on an islet called Häggholmen
column3: which due to post-glacial rebound almost has become a part of the mainland; the land in northern Sweden rises at a rate of up to 9 mm (0.35 in) per year.

column2: with numerous islands and inlets
column3: is one of the reasons it is a popular place for tourism both in summer and winter. It features a beach resort area called Pite Havsbad
column4: around which there is a spa
column6: a restaurant and a golf course. The area is also suitable for fishing and outdoor activities. In the winter
column7: snow activities such as skiing and winter bathing are common. The water temperatures reportedly being Sweden's warmest during three consecutive summers in the 1950s
column8: the beach then became known as "Norrbotten's Riviera".

column1: Piteå has a climate that is classified as subarctic climate (Köppen climate classification Dfc)
column2: bordering to a Humid continental climate (Köppen climate classification Dfb).

column1: The warmest months in Piteå are June
column2: July
column4: with high temperatures of 17 to 30 °C (63 to 86 °F). The coldest are December
column7: with low temperatures of −22 to −10 °C (−8 to 14 °F).

column1: Piteå received its city privileges on 12 May 1621. The town was originally situated slightly north of its current location
column2: in present-day Öjebyn. In July 1666
column4: and over the following few years it was rebuilt on Häggholmen
column5: a small island which forms the nucleus of present-day Piteå. In 1721
column6: the new town was burnt down by Russian troops during the Russian Pillage of 1719-1721
column7: and the only building that remained was the church

column2: where the town hall is located
column3: has kept its structure from the 17th century. It is one of only two squares in Sweden with closed corners; the other one is in Uppsala.

column1: Piteå's population has increased rapidly since the 19th century. In the years 1870–1920
column2: Piteå had a population of only 2
column3: 500 people. Part of the early population increase is attributed to the 1911 opening of the Älvsbyn-Piteå railway branch
column4: as well as industrial establishments and the harbour.

column1: Piteå has traditionally had a strong forestry industry; papermills
column2: sawmills
column3: and its harbour are of some importance.

column1: Piteå is known for its pitepalt
column2: a food dish consisting of potato dumplings with chopped pork filling. The area is also known for its dialect
column4: which however is mainly spoken by elders in surrounding villages.

column1: Piteå has a fast food drive-thru commonly used by snowmobilers.  The restaurant was a McDonald's from February 2002 to November 2007. Several McDonald's restaurants in Norrbotten closed at the time
column2: in the face of competition from Max Hamburgers. The restaurant is now part of the Frasses hamburger chain.  The drive-thru has received international coverage
column3: including on The Travel Channel in an episode called "Most Unique McDonald's".Piteå has a sister city in the Caribbean: Gustavia
column5: the formerly Swedish possession that is now part of France.

column1: Piteå has emerged as an important center of cleantech production and research based on cellulose byproducts. Chemrec operates a black liquor gasifier and the world's first BioDME production facility
column2: SunPine has pioneered a renewable diesel process technology using crude tall oil as feedstock
column3: and ETC (Energy Technology Centre in Piteå) is a research and development center for renewable fuels with focus on combustion

column1: The Piteå IF football team is playing in the fourth highest Swedish division
column2: Division 2 for men; and the Piteå IF ladies team is for their first time playing in the highest league in football

column1: Ice hockey is the big sport in town
column2: even though Piteå HC only plays in the third-highest League (Division I) in Sweden.  The club has provided many good players to the NHL and national team: examples are Tomas Holmström
column7: Jan Sandström and Mats Lavander. Munksund-Skuthamns SK ladies team is
column9: playing in the highest league in Hockey
column10: Riksserien. Rebecka Stenberg became the first woman from town playing for Swedish national team.

column1: In cross-country skiing the town has a successful club called Piteå Elit
column2: with skiers like Lina Andersson

the town has a very successful team called Piteå Sim which is famous all over Norrland especially Norrbotten. One of the most famous swimmers in the club is 13-year-old Heidi Nilsson who got first place in the Junior
column3: Senior and Ladies category in the Piteå Kanalsimmet 2018 which takes place every year on Valborgsmässoafton.

column1: Other sports clubs located in Piteå include Storfors AIK
column2: MSSK and the northern paintball team 'Team X-rated'.
